title: Shamoon Alam Khan
text:
<a href="Vice-Admiral">Vice-Admiral</a> Shamoon Alam Khan (<a href="Urdu">Urdu</a>: شمعون عالم) , is a retired <a href="Three-star%20rank">three-star</a> rank admiral in the <a href="Pakistan%20Navy">Pakistan Navy</a> and a diplomat.
Biography.
Shamoon Alam Khan was born in <a href="Shillong">Shillong</a>, <a href="Meghalaya">Meghalaya</a> in <a href="British%20Indian%20Empire">India</a>, into an <a href="Urdu-speaking">Urdu-speaking</a> family, and his father, Mahboob Alam Khan, was an officer in the <a href="Indian%20Civil%20Service%20%28British%20India%29">Indian Civil Service</a> who worked at an administration position at the <a href="Survey%20of%20India">Survey of India</a>. His mother, Nisa Begum, was a <a href="housewife">housewife</a>. His father, Mahboob Alam, had nine children with Nisa among all joined the respected branches of the <a href="Pakistan%20Armed%20Forces">Pakistan Armed Forces</a>. His older brother, <a href="Shamim%20Alam%20Khan">Shamim</a> was a career officer who became <a href="Chairman%20Joint%20Chiefs%20of%20Staff%20Committee">Chairman Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee</a> in the 1990s.
After the <a href="Partition%20of%20India">partition</a> of <a href="British%20Indian%20Empire">India</a> in 1947, the Allam family moved from <a href="Bangalore">Bangalore</a> to <a href="Rawalpindi">Rawalpindi</a> via <a href="Indian%20Railways">train</a>, where the Allam brothers witnessed the <a href="Violence%20against%20Muslims%20in%20India">violence and riots</a> that were taking place in the trains at the time of the partition in 1947. Eventually, Mahboob Alam found the employment at the <a href="Survey%20of%20Pakistan">Survey of Pakistan</a>.
After his <a href="Matriculation%20in%20Pakistan">matriculation</a>, Shamoon, along with <a href="Shamim%20Alam%20Khan">Shamim</a>, went to attend the <a href="Lawrence%20College%2C%20Murree">Lawrence College</a> where he earned the <a href="High%20school%20diploma">diploma</a>. In 1955, he joined the <a href="Pakistan%20Navy">Pakistan Navy</a> and was selected to be trained at the <a href="Britannia%20Royal%20Naval%20College">Britannia Royal Naval College</a> at <a href="Dartmouth%2C%20Devon">Dartmouth</a> in <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>, trained as a <a href="Surface%20warfare%20insignia">surface officer</a>.
In the 1960s, <a href="Lieutenant%20%28naval%29">Lt.</a> Shamoon served as an <a href="Executive%20officer">Executive officer</a> at various <a href="List%20of%20active%20Pakistan%20Navy%20ships">surface warships</a>, and participated in the <a href="Operation%20Dwarka">naval offence</a> against the <a href="Indian%20Navy">Indian Navy</a> during the <a href="Indo-Pakistani%20War%20of%201965">second war</a> with <a href="India">India</a> in 1965. In 1967, <a href="Lieutenant%20%28naval%29">Lt.</a> Shamoon joined the <a href="Inter-Services%20Intelligence">Inter-Services Intelligence</a> (ISI), and was posted in <a href="East%20Pakistan">East Pakistan</a>, working on the <a href="Intelligence%20gathering%20network">intelligence gathering</a>.
For a short period of time, <a href="Lieutenant-Commander">Lieutenant-Commander</a> Shamoon provided and ran a short training course to the junior officers graduating from the <a href="Pakistan%20Naval%20Academy">Naval Academy</a> in <a href="Karachi">Karachi</a> at the <a href="HMS%20Diadem%20%2884%29">PNS "Babur"</a> near the <a href="Bay%20of%20Bengal">Bay of Bengal</a>.
In 1970–71, <a href="Lieutenant-Commander">Lt-Cdr.</a> Shamoon moved his ISI office in <a href="Comilla%20District">Comilla</a>, and took participation in briefing the formations of <a href="Pakistan%20Marines">Pakistan Marines</a> and special forces of <a href="Special%20Service%20Group">Army</a> and <a href="Special%20Service%20Group%20%28Navy%29">Navy</a> to commence offence on approaching <a href="Indian%20Army">Indian Army</a>. During the height of the <a href="Bangladesh%20Liberation%20War">civil insurgency</a> in <a href="East%20Pakistan">East-Pakistan</a>, <a href="Lieutenant-Commander">Lt-Cdr.</a> Shamoon volunteered into the entrance in the <a href="Special%20Service%20Group%20%28Navy%29">Navy Special Service Group</a> and was a commanding officer of the <a href="Special%20Service%20Group%20%28Navy%29">Navy SEAL Team</a> that conducted a <a href="reconnaissance">reconnaissance</a> mission to gain knowledge on the <a href="Indian%20Army">Indian Army</a>'s movement near the <a href="Rangamati%20Hill%20District">Rangamati</a>, leading to insert the <a href="Pakistan%20Marines">Pakistan Marines</a> <a href="battalion">battalion</a>s, and later made a way to secure intelligence on the <a href="Kaptai%20Dam">Kaptai Dam</a>.
In 1971, <a href="Lieutenant-Commander">Lt-Cdr.</a> Shamoon was taken <a href="Pakistani%20prisoners%20of%20war%20in%20India">war prisoner</a> by <a href="Indian%20Army">Indian Army</a> after the <a href="Instrument%20of%20Surrender%20%281971%29">unilateral surrender</a> was signed and expatriated to Pakistan in 1973. In 1974, <a href="Commander%20%28rank%29">Cdr.</a> Shamoon remained associated with the <a href="ISI%20%28Pakistan%29">ISI</a> for remainder of his career, and was directed to attend the <a href="National%20Defence%20University%2C%20Pakistan">Armed Forces War College</a> (afwc) at the <a href="National%20Defence%20University%2C%20Pakistan">National Defence University</a>, and attained <a href="Master%20of%20science">MSc</a> in <a href="War%20studies">War studies</a> in the class of 1976.
His first diplomatic assignment included <a href="Captain%20%28naval%29">Capt.</a> Shamoon's appointment as a <a href="Naval%20attache">Naval attache'</a> at the <a href="Embassy%20of%20Pakistan">Pakistan Embassy</a> in <a href="Beijing">Beijing</a> in 1981. In 1983, <a href="Captain%20%28naval%29">Capt.</a> Shamoon was promoted as a <a href="One-star%20rank">one-star</a> rank admiral in the Navy, and was selected to attend a year-long staff course at the <a href="Royal%20College%20of%20Defence%20Studies">Royal College of Defence Studies</a> (RCDS) in <a href="London">London</a>. Upon returning, <a href="Commodore%20%28rank%29">Cdre.</a> Shamoon was appointed <a href="commandant">commandant</a> of the <a href="Pakistan%20Naval%20Academy">Pakistan Naval Academy</a> in <a href="Karachi">Karachi</a> in 1987–88, and later served as commandant of the <a href="Joint%20Staff%20Headquarters%20%28Pakistan%29">Joint Staff College</a> in <a href="Chaklala%2C%20Rawalpindi">Chaklala</a>.
In the 1990s, <a href="Rear-Admiral">Rear-Admiral</a> Shamoon's <a href="Two-star%20rank">two-star</a> rank assignments included his role as <a href="Deputy%20Chief%20of%20the%20Naval%20Staff%20%28Pakistan%29">DCNS (Training)</a> at the <a href="NHQ%20%28Pakistan%20Navy%29">Navy NHQ</a>. In 1993, <a href="Rear-Admiral">R-Adm.</a> Shamoon was promoted to the <a href="Three-star%20rank">three-star</a> rank, and eventually appointed senior fleet commander of the <a href="Pakistan%20Navy%23Naval%20Commands%20in%20Field%20and%20Commanders">Pakistan Fleet</a>. <a href="Vice-Admiral">V-Adm.</a> Shamoon played a vital role increasing the security role of the <a href="ISI%20%28Pakistan%29">ISI</a> in sea-based operations while strengthening <a href="Karachi%20Coast">coastal defence</a> by empowering the <a href="Maritime%20Security%20Agency">MSA</a>'s capabilities in search and rescue operations. In 1995, <a href="Vice-Admiral">V-Adm.</a> Shamoon eventually sought his retirement after completing 40-years of military service.
After his retirement, Shamoon joined the <a href="Foreign%20Service%20of%20Pakistan">Foreign Service</a>, and was appointed in 1995, which he served until 1997. In 2001, Shamoon was appointed and sent as a , which he served until 2004.
